title: What societies in history had the least herd based thinking? - Quora

response.answer_text: While countries that form the modern developed world by and large share similar attributes, the genesis of individual freedom lies in the British society. It all started in the late 17th century when the British society witnessed drastic change in form of the bloodless Glorious Revolution in 1688 when King James II of England was overthrown by a union of Parliamentarians. It was one of the final and decisive developments in the power struggle between the Parliament and the Monarchy in England. Never again would the monarch pretend to hold absolute power and the Bill of Rights 1689 became one of the most important documents in the political history of Britain (and later the developed world). The philosopher John Locke praised the Glorious Revolution in his Two Treatises on Government (1689), arguing that if a government does not protect the natural rights of its people, namely life, liberty and property, it can rightly and lawfully be overthrown. Locke's praise of the Glorious Revolution helped to inspire both the American and French revolutions. The individual empowerment and respect of an individual’s ideas made the British society least herd like. This massive social change also was behind the Industrial Revolution in Britain only and nowhere else in the world. The modern day British society continues to lead the world till date, in being least herd based.
